chapter.title: SIA: Writing a Paragraph Explanation (ESL)
chapter.content:
[Teacher starts at the front of the room with a whiteboard. Class has 10-12 adult learners facing the board. Student are at long tables – can work in pairs easily.]

Teacher [indicating a picture of a hamburger on the board]: Let’s take a look at this hamburger, and let’s analyze the parts of the hamburger. Okay, if we’re looking at the hamburger— okay, imagine that this is a real hamburger—what do you see first here? [Teacher points to the top bun.] Okay, you see the bun! You see the top, is a bun. Okay, we have a bun… What comes after the bun here? [points to the lettuce] The lettuce! Okay, next you have the lettuce. [teacher writes “lettuce” next to the lettuce.] After the lettuce… [some students say, “Tomato”] you have tomato… [writes “tomato” next to it]… [teacher looks at the next layer] Oh! Okay!

Student: Onions…

Teacher: Onions, okay… [writes “onion” next to the picture]

Students: Mayo…

Student: No! No mayo!

[students laugh]

Teacher: It might be there, but some people don’t like mayo…

Teacher [pointing to the meat layer]: And then what is this? That’s the meat [writes “meat” on the picture] And then, here, we have…? [teacher indicates the bottom bun, writes “bun”.] Okay, we have another bun, that’s the bottom. [adds the word “bottom” after the bottom bun]

Student: No pickle?

Teacher: Maybe, I don’t see any pickle—that’s a good question! That’s a good question: Can you add pickles to a hamburger? Yes. Can you add mayo? Yes. Can you add mustard? Ketchup? Can you add… [holds up a picture of cookies] cookies?

Students: No!

Teacher: Why not?

[students murmur answers]

Teacher: Do you like cookies? Okay, right, cookies do not belong on a hamburger, do they?

[students say something about cookies on a hamburger] A ‘good experience’? A new experience! A cookie burger! [holds up picture of spaghetti] Okay, can you add spaghetti?

Students: No!

Teacher: Why not?

Student: It does not belong there.

Teacher: It doesn’t belong; it’s not part of a hamburger, it doesn’t belong. [holds up picture of fruit] How about fruit?

Students: No!

Teacher: No. Okay, how about this one? [holds up picture of bacon] How about bacon?

Students: Yes.

Teacher: Some people like bacon, and some people say no, but you could possibly add bacon. So some things belong in the hamburger and some things do not belong, because that is not what a hamburger is.

So, now we’re going to take a look at the hamburger again, and we’re going to see how a hamburger can help you remember to organize your writing. [holding up another picture of a hamburger] So if you will look at this paper, I’m going to read it. I’d like you to read along with me, okay? Okay, so, what is a paragraph? [reads from the picture she holds.] “A paragraph is a group of sentences that all talk about the same topic.” What is a ‘topic’, class?

Student: The most important idea of a paragraph.

Teacher: Okay, so, a topic is the idea, what something is about. Okay, so it could be an important idea. Okay, so, a paragraph talks about one topic. Think of a paragraph as a delicious hamburger, mmm, that you want your readers to enjoy eating. Like a hamburger, your paragraph will have different parts [she refers back to the drawing of the hamburger on the board, and points to the different layers]. All the parts are very important if the hamburger is going to hold together and be delicious!

Okay, if I take the bottom bun off, what happens? [students shake heads, murmur about what happens] What happens if I take the top bun off? What if I take the meat out?

[students react with murmurs.]

Teacher: Okay, and if I take the lettuce, tomato and onion out? It’s not going to be as good, is it? So the hamburgers have certain parts that make it delicious; in the same way, all of the sentences in a paragraph are important.

Okay. So we’re going to take a look now at the hamburger and see how it will help you remember what sentences you need in your paragraph.

So, first, the top of the bun: that’s your ‘topic sentence’. This important sentence introduces your reader to the paragraph. The topic sentence tells your readers what the paragraph is about. And it usually—not always, but it usually comes at the beginning. [refers to drawing on board.] So what is the top bun going to be?

Students: the topic sentence.

Teacher: Right, that’s going to be your topic sentence. [She writes “topic sentence” at the top of the drawing.] Okay, next… [She indicates the middle sections of the burger]… we’re going to look at the juicy part… “B”, this section, is going to be called the “supporting details”. What is support, what does “supporting” mean?

Student: You have to, uh, add the ingredients, and if you write something, you have to have something to help you explain what you want to say, what you want to write…

Teacher: Right.

Student: So you help.

Teacher: It holds it up, right…

Student: And support the topic idea.

Teacher: Good, all right, yes! So, the next sentences (“sentences”) gives interesting, and as you said, important details that support and explain the topic sentence—and they always stick to the topic! Just like cookies don’t belong in the hamburger, you can’t have sentences that don’t stick to your topic of your paragraph. So here, we have “topic sentence”, then we have, what, again?

Students: Supporting details.

Teacher [adds this phrase to picture on board]: Supporting details.

So now… You can’t have a hamburger without the bottom of the bun, so let’s see what the bottom of the bun is in your paragraph. That’s your “concluding sentence”. This sentence closes the paragraph; it gives a summary of what the paragraph is about, but it’s not simply a repeat of the topic sentence.

So, what is this section called? [she indicates the bottom bun on the drawing.]

Students: Concluding sentence. Conclusion.

Teacher [adds the phrase to the picture on the board]: “Concluding sentence”. Now, without the bottom bun, the hamburger falls apart. But do you notice that both the top bun and the bottom bun are both made of bread? They’re similar, but they’re not the same. So your topic sentence and your concluding sentence are going to be similar, but not the same.
